dialogues.text: (to Cooper) Hi, baby. What's goin' on? Mason and Samantha walk down to the pond.   Annie sits on picnic bench with Cooper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I think we're just gonna hang out here for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to stay with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samantha pushes a stick into the mud.   Mason photographs pond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason, why are you such a stick-in- the-mud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you even talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you guys don't mind coming back here on the 20th, do you, for Cooper's baptism?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate it. It means a lot to Annie and her folks, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were we baptized? They share a look and laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't the least bit concerned with the state of your soul. We can do it now, though, if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, nah, I think I'm alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Cooper together, you know. Dunk your heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not becoming one of those God people, are you, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's that supposed to mean, hm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can hear you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think that shotgun should live at my house, huh. I don't think your mom would love that. Dad picks up a rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look out, Sam. Let me show you how it's done. Dad skips the rock across the pond.   Mason photographs i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice, Dad. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still got the goods, hmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason is developing a picture in the darkroom.   His teac MR. TURLINGTON, wanders in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long you been in here, Mason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure. All class. Did you complete your image diary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Completed your, uh, digital contact sheet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite, but... I mean, it's not gonna take me long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. Not quite. Darkroom time is extra-curricular. I mean technically, you don't ever have to be in here these days, and certainly not until you've completed your assignments. That's the deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm worried about you, Mason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you why. The images you're turning in, they're cool. You're looking at things in a really unique way. Got a lot of natural talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but, that and fifty cents will just get you a cup of coffee in this old world. I've met a lot of talented people over the years. How many of them made it professionally without discipline, commitment, and a really good work ethic? Mason shrugs and shakes his head, unsure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell you. I can count it on two fingers. Zero. It's not gonna happen for you, Mason. The world is too competitive. There are too many talented people who are willing to work hard. And a butt-load of morons who are untalented, who are more than willing to surpass you. As a matter of fact, a lot of them are sitting in that classroom out there right now. Hm? You know what they're doing? They're doing their assignments, which is what you're supposed to be doing, but you're not. You're in here. Why is that? Are you special, Mason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I mean the things you're talking about, like work ethic or whatever, I feel like I do work pretty hard. I spend the whole weekend taking pictures a lot of times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like football, Mason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know you don't. That's why I've just assigned you to shoot the football game tonight. Okay? It starts at 7:30. I want you to get there early. I want you to shoot a full card, three hundred images, and I want 'em downloaded, I want 'em sorted, and I want to see them very first thing Monday. Okay? You want to know why I'm doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you want to be, Mason?    What do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to take pictures.    Make art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any dip-shit can take pictures, Mason. Art, that's special. What can you bring to it that nobody else can?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm trying to find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try harder. Hey, maybe in twenty years you can call old Mr. Turlington and you can say, "Thank you, sir, for that terrific dark room chat we had that day." (walking away) Get back to class and do your work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason walks back to his computer.    NICK sits at the neighboring computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey man.   You're walkin' a little funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying, you guys were in there for a long time. Just hope he bought you dinner first. Mason playfully jabs Nick in the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim sits at the kitchen table, opening a beer. Mom and Samantha prepare dinner in the kitchen. Mom walks over to the stairs to call up to Mason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason!   Honey, come down for dinner. On her way back to the kitchen, Mom notices the screen on open laptop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samantha! You didn't post these pictures and their descriptions? Come on, this auction is going to end on Sunday, honey. You've got to get those posted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are we even doing this? It's like an online junk shop. I thought you had a good job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. We're what you call house poor. Everyone's got to do their part. Your brother took the pictures. You have to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who even buys this shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Sam, watch your mouth, alright? Don't disrespect your mother. You like a roof over your head, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and you like having electricity so that you can charge your cell phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not even gonna be here next year. I'm a senior. I should be having fun. Mason enters. He sits down at the table.   He has blue na polish on his fingernails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, some girl did that in sixth period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You planning on keeping them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until it comes off, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last summer it was the earrings, and now the nails. You got a, uh, you got a purse to go with all that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of guys do that.   He's just trying to be cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was in high school, having a job, being responsible, being able to afford a car, that was cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason, honey, why don't you get you and your sister some water. Mason gets up to help set the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An announcer comments on the game over the loud speaker. The crowd cheers and the band plays. Mason is on the sidelines, photographing details he finds interesting. He scrolls through the images on his camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey man, Turlington says to cut the artsy crap and shoot the game. So take your lens and point it that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also, we got a ride tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCormick gonna take us to the party. We're gonna head out after the game. You're goin', okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot the game. A player catches the ball and is tackled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "She's Long Gone" by the Black Keys plays over the party. Mason fills a cup at the keg. Samantha takes a shot with boy. Kids play beer bong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kobe... It goes in - guests react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! First one. What was that? What was that? What is up? Nick plays drums with teen band.    Mason approaches SHEE He nudges her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.    How's it goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty good.     How long have you been here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Awhile, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awhile?    Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason and Sheena sit and talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just feel like there are so many things that I could be doing and probably want to be doing that I'm just not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I guess it's... just being afraid of what people would think. You know, judgment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I guess it's really easy to say, like, I don't care what anyone else thinks, but, everyone does, you know? Deep down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. I find myself so furious at all these people that I'm in contact with just for controlling me or whatever, but you know, they're not even aware they're doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. So... in this perfect world where no one's controlling you, what's different? What changes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything. I mean, I just    wanna be able to do anything I want,   because it makes me feel alive. As    opposed to giving me the appearance   of normality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever that means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it means much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kinda weird, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Laughing) Is that a compliment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Do you wanna be weird?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I don't want to like... scare kids at the park, or anything like that. Sheena laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really like talking with you. I don't usually even try to like vocalize my thoughts or feelings or anything. Just, I don't know, it just never sounds right. Words are stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, why're you trying with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I guess I feel comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason comes home late. Jim sits outside on a chair surrou by empty beer cans and one in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jim.   I'm sorry I'm so late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time were you supposed to be home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Awhile ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awhile ago like, thirty minutes ago, an hour ago? Cause, truthfully, nobody even knew where you were until your sister told us. She's been home for awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, been hearin' a lot of that lately. See, but you don't actually care. You just kinda... kinda come and go as you please and you don't care if your mom's upset or what time you gotta be home... Is that what's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop mumbling! You know, speak up! I can't understand a word comin' outta your mouth. It's just like, "uh uhh nuhh" and I ask you questions and you just--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, can I just have one day where everyone isn't all over my ass!? Jim gets up abruptly and advances on Mason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm up your ass? This is my house. Now, if you wanna live in my house then you get home when you say you're gonna be home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Jim, you're not my dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not your dad! You know how I know that? Cause I'm actually here. I'm the guy with the job, paying the bills, taking care of you, your mom, your sister... Huh?! Huh?! Mason goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm that guy... Jim sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom sits at the kitchen table surrounded by bills and pap Mason comes down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning. Hey, which one of you guys used the downstairs bathroom last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That tall guy, what's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Phillip. He did it. Can Phillip read? I mean, there's a big sign on the door, it says, "Do not use this bathroom, it's broken." I mean, how difficult is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm sorry. Mason prepares cereal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm gonna put the house on the market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This house is too big for us. I mean, you're going to school eventually... It's too expensive. I'm done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well why did you even buy it in the first place, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I really enjoy making poor life decisions, keeping us on the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: brink of poverty. I mean, I've spent the first half of my life acquiring all this crap and now I'm gonna spend the second half of my life getting rid of all this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?   Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like - Well, I got rid of a couple husbands, now I'm gonna get rid of a mortgage, some maintenance, the tchotchkes, the, the homeowner's insurance, the property tax, the plumbing... Ahhh. You know what? From now on I am gonna be Mommy Monk. Simple. Celibate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be gross, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. I'll be a poor whore with a big house. (Laughs) Is that better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Mason starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason -- Mason, please, don't leave me that dirty dish to wash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do dishes all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, great honey, then you're a professional. Come on, you could do one or two more for you poor old mom. Mason walks over to the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason gets in truck, drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music plays in the background. Mason is in uniform, he carries in a bus tub of dirty dishes, one with uneaten battered shrimp on it. He sticks one in his mouth and fli with APRIL, a waitress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh. God --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Laughing) She didn't even touch them, seriously. I watched her the whole time. April takes one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I bet you did watch her, you little pervert. (Laughing) It's like we're on a date. Cheers. They clink battered shrimp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a night of romance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, except I'm not gonna kiss you. She heads back out to the restaurant floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will blow you, though. Mason brings the dishes over to the industrial washers. boss, MR. WOOD, storms in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason!   We are in the weeds out here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm goin' as fast as I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I must be confused then, cause I just saw you chattin it up with April when I gotta salad bar that needs a refill, I gotta six top, two four tops I can't use, because they haven't been bused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enrique is not here.   I'm tryin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, while you're tryin', we're dyin'! What am I supposed to tell my customers? "Oh, I'm sorry that your table's got dirty plates on it, but Mason's tryin'. Least that's what he told me, after he was flirtin' with April and eatin' your leftover shrimp." Now it is a challenge out there today, I know, but I wanna share somethin' with you, I got you pegged for fry cook this summer, now that's a lot more responsibility. It's also more money. How's that sound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you can handle that money... but can you take the responsibility? I think you can, because I believe in you. But I need you on the floor. Now leave the dishes. Giddyup. Right, come on, don't let me down! Mason exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason sits on the stairs video chatting with Dad on his p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, so it's -- it's runnin' okay? That alternator's not messin' up anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Holding Phone) No , it's fine. It's up for the trip.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (Laughing) Well, you gonna see your sister when you guys are in Austin?

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Yeah, she said I can stay at her dorm, which is cool, and I guess her roommate's out of town so it's no big deal.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Alright, well, did you apply there yet? Did you get that application in to UT?

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Not yet, but Sheena's pretty much in, though.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. Well, if you know that's where you wanna go, you should probably do that early acceptance thing. You know? I mean seriously, let 'em know you're a man who knows what he wants.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: A bit of decisiveness goes a long way in this life, alright?

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Great. And uh, what about work? How's that goin'?

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Uh, I don't know. It's, it's alright. Today kind of sucked, this guy didn't show up. But it's definitely an interesting perspective on the world. People are slobs.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (Laughing) Well, when people ask me about you I say, "Oh, Mason, he's doing great. He's got a job, he's really cleanin' up."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (From Phone) Alright, hey, hey, say hi to Annie and Cooper, will you? Dad pans the phone to Annie and baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say hi to your big brother.     Hey, big brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Annie.    Hey, kiddo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you say bye-bye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye-buh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Laughs) We'll see you soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (From phone) Alright, alright, well, be careful when you're driving, alright? Don't be texting, don't be doing any of that. Alright? Just, you're Obi Wan. You're centered, patient, right? You watch three cars ahead, two behind. It takes two bad drivers to have an accident okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (From phone) Right, and listen, tell your sister to pick up her phone or call me back or something. Mom comes down the stairs and drops a bag at Mason's feet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, buddy!      You have a good one.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Bye, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: (Motioning to the bag) Hey, honey, take this to your sister. Throw it in the truck, okay?

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Okay, I will.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: So where is Sheena staying?

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: At her friend Emily's.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Is Emily a real person?

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: (Laughing) Yeah. Yeah, she's a sophomore.    She has an apartment.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: (Holding out money) Okay, this is in case of emergency. Don't spend it. I want it back.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Okay.   Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Did you do your homework?

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Most of it, but... I can finish tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Honey! Eleventh grade is really important for college. Don't blow it.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: I know! I know. I mean, we're going to UT and everything.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: I know, and don't you want me to come? Come on, Sheena, road trip with Mom! I'll pay for gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Umm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just kidding.      I have work. She kisses his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me when you get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have fun! Mason exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Suburban Wars" plays.    Mason drives, Sheena is in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... That sounds to me like just another extreme Mason view of everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all! I finally figured it out. It's like when they realized it was gonna be too expensive to actually build cyborgs and robots... I mean, the costs of that were impossible. They decided to just let humans turn themselves into robots. That's what's going on right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! I mean, why not? There are billions of us just laying around, not really doing anything. We don't cost anything. I mean we're even pretty good at self-maintenance and reproducing constantly. And as it turns out, we're already biologically programmed for our little cyborg upgrades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously. I read this thing other day about how, like, when you hear that ding on your inbox you get a, like a dopamine rush in your brain. It's like we're being chemically rewarded for allowing ourselves to be brainwashed. How evil is that? We're fucked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you deleting your Facebook page is gonna change all that? Remember when Trevor deleted his Facebook page last year and everyone just hated him? You made more fun of him than anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still make fun of Trevor, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it looked like he was so pathetically desperate for attention. Or to be different, or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just 'cause they did that lame story about it in the school paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then he had to make a big announcement about it when he came back a month later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the thing though, I'm not doing it for attention. I just want to try and not live my life through a screen. I want, like, some kind of actual interaction. A real person, not just the profile they put up. Sheena's looking at her phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry. Were you saying something? She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay, I know you're joking, but, I mean, it's kinda true you have been, you know, checking your phone this whole time, and so what are you really doing? You don't care what your friends are up to on Saturday afternoon but you're also obviously not fully experiencing my profound bitching so... it's like everyone's just stuck in, like, an in-between state. Not really experiencing anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not an experience, it's just information. Look, for example, I just got the address of the club where we're meeting them later, so we won't be wandering the streets of Austin lost for an hour tonight. Thank you very much, Facebook. And I just texted my mom back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's -- that's groundbreaking. She hasn't seen you in, like, 55 minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Oh my god, most importantly, Meg's family just got a miniature pet pig. Sheena hands him the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at phone photo) Hm! (Laughs) Okay, you're right.    That is a --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a really cute, tiny pig. Our lives can go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want one.

dialogues.text: You're gonna be doing some good work out there. Think about it, awful lot of flowers in that bouquet. But, you gotta do me a favor. You're going to be vulnerable this summer, alright. Remember to use protection during breakup sex. He puts his hand on Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy knows exactly of which I speak. Look what happened to him. Viola'. Uncle Steve gestures to Mason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chanting) Four more years. Four more years. I'm just saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later Dad enters the kitchen where Mom happens to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do y'all recycle?   Should I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have one started there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, right. Okay, great. Okay. Am I, uh, am I your only ex at this party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but I'm not your only wife here, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe they're both out of high school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No, I can't. (a beat) You did a great job with both of them, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for saying that. I never thought I'd hear you say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's true.    Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're doing it all over again, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know, right? It's gonna be uh, fifteen years till I have an empty nest. But hey, I'd love to pitch in, help with this, if I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, it's so great that you did this. I was just going to give you a little. I'd appreciate it if I could. He pulls out his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.   Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But I don't have any cash. It's in Annie's purse. I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason and Dad are wandering through the green room area w the band is doing a sound check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...So it sucks. I mean, the guy's a college lacrosse player. I mean, what are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't even like sports. An iced-down bucket of drinks beckons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. They continue their conversation out of the green room to little area overlooking the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, for what it's worth, we've all been through the exact same thing, at one point or another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the same, though.     I mean, you never got to know her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I know, I know.    It's not the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't know what I did wrong. At this point Dad yells down to Jimmy, his roommate from years before, briefly interrupting the sound check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jimmy.    Hey, man.   Hey --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're up here raiding the green room. Hope that's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's totally cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow!   Is that M.J.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.    Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we just decided to come a little early, check you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's cool man, let me finish up, I'll be up in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, alright. He and Mason slowly start to drift around the venue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to Mason) I guarantee you, you didn't do anything wrong. These high school love things, they never work out. Here, come here.

dialogues.speaker: DAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, everyone's just changing so much. The odds of two young people staying on the same wavelength are...

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Yeah, but still --

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Look, and I also guarantee you that every day of your life that you spend crying over some silly girl is a complete waste of time.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: She wasn't a silly girl, though.   I mean, she's a serious person. I really thought we were --

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Here's the truth. Women are never satisfied. Ok? They're always looking to potentially trade up and that's, I'm sorry to say, what I think has happened to you my fine feathered friend.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: What does that even mean?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: It means don't hand over the controls to your self-esteem to Sheila.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Sheena.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Alright. It means you are responsible for you, not your girlfriend, not your mom, not me. You. And if you truly take care of you, you will be amazed at how much girls like Sheena start lining up at your front door.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Yeah, you know, you just gotta separate yourself from the pack in some way. Excel at something, you know, and then you have your pick of the litter when them front-running hussies start sniffing around.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: So what you're saying is, I should take up lacrosse.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Exactly. Or you could, you know, start a band. Worked for me a long time ago. I think it's still working for Jimmy. Or you just keep taking pictures.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: She hated the pictures I took of her.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Alright. I'm sick to death of her, okay? I only met her a few times and yes she was cute, alright. But, truth be told I always thought she was a little bit, you know, a little bit too square for you. Y'know, not quite the same vibe.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: You really thought that?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: On some subtle, lower level. I mean, uh, I wasn't surprised when it turned out she was interested in some knucklehead lacrosse player, okay? I mean, bottom line is, it's all timing with these things. Y'know. I mean, uh, take your mom and me. Y'know I think I probably turned into the boring castrated guy she wanted me to be fifteen or twenty years ago, y'know? And man I'm not saying she was wrong to be pissed. I'm not, I'm just saying that, y'know, she could have been a little more patient... a little more forgiving.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Would've saved me that parade of drunken assholes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad gestures zipping his lip, saying nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, any of this. Everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything? What's the point? I mean I sure as shit don't know. I mean, but, neither does anybody else. Okay, we're all just winging it, you know? I mean the good news is you're feeling stuff. You know? And you got to hold onto that. You do. I mean you get older and you don't feel as much. You're skin gets tougher. The point is those pictures you took. Thousands of submissions from all over the state and you won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I got silver.   And nine other people did, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna kill you. I'm tryin' to tell you that I believe in you, Mason. I think you're really special, and if some girl doesn't see that, then fuck her, y'know? Jimmy's at the mic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, this next one goes out to a young man in the house --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woo-oho!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Known him since he was just a small boy, now he's all graduated from high school, making me feel old. Happy high school graduation, Mason. He plays his guitar, and the band kicks in... sounding pr great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, Mason and Samantha sit down at a table.     A waitre places menus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Okay guys, let's be clear. I'm going to break this into four categories. One. Anything you wanna keep from your childhood and your taking with you. Two. Throwing away. Three. Donating. Four. Whatever you wanna try to sell at the garage sell next weekend, whatever we don't sell, we're donating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't the apartment have like an attic, or storage or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You're missing the point. We're not going to drag a bunch of crap to mom's tiny apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't believe we're moving again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm moving! You moved two years ago. You have an apartment in Austin. Mason is moving the fall. I'm done. This will be great for me. I'll have all these options. I could take a sabbatical. I could get some writing done and try to get published.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Christmas, though?   What are we gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sharing a room with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of you will sleep on the couch, and we'll use that blow-up mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I supposed to do my laundry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, I'm gently pushing you out of the nest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on your way down you may magically find some quarters that you use to do laundry in your own apartment. Come on! You guys are adults. You need to take some responsibility! And what do you want? Mom puts her glasses on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get the veggie burger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not having anything, not hungry. Mom takes her glasses off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, your head?   Do you have a fever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weak laugh) No. To be honest, I drank way too much last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't driving, were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. Carrie's back home, too, and we just hung out. You know, peach Smirnoffs, they just go down so easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. Hey - that's not an excuse. You can still pack boxes. These people want to move in as soon as possible. The assistant restaurant manager, who'll we'll come to kn as ERNESTO, approaches the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi guys. I'm Ernesto, how are you? (to Mom) Uh, you probably don't remember me, but I worked on your septic line years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe it or not, you changed my life. Yeah, you told me that day that I was smart and that I should go to school. I took your advice! I signed up for English classes and then a year later I went to community college and I got my associates degree. And I'm working on my bachelors now at Texas State. And I'm also one of the managers here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, it's good to see you. Because I really wanted a chance to thank you for that. Gracias. It really meant a lot to me. Don't worry about lunch. It's on me. It's the least I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys should listen to her.   She's a smart lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Ernesto walks back toward the kitchen, leaving the three seated at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason, now with a scruffy beard, is wedging a duffel bag bin into the bed of his truck. He walks back toward Mom's new apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason is packing a box, in mid-conversation with Mom, who seated in another room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Isn't that kind of crazy though, that a computer knows who you are from just twenty questions off a form? I guess there are really only like eight types of people in the world. Mom goes to the kitchen and pours coffee into a mug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean there are subsets, like male and female, but apparently we're not as unique as we want to think we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you even talked to this guy yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but we've been trading emails. He seems pretty cool. He's studying literature, and uh, anthropology, and he's way into Bright Eyes... so that's not so bad. But anyways, he was telling me about how the system they use for assigning roommates is kind of spooky. Like, the Freshmen satisfaction rate for new roommates used to be like 60%, and now it's 100%. Just cause of the computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. Sounds like he'll be a good roommate, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But we've pretty much decided that soon they won't even need a questionnaire. Because they'll just let the NSA scan your digital ghost, and they'll tell you who your roommate is, based on everything you've ever said, written, or clicked. Mason walks back into the living room, carrying a box. holds up a framed picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you -- Did you put this in here again? Mom laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, it's the first picture you ever took.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I mean, all the more reason to leave it behind, right? Mason goes to put the picture back in his room, while Mom suddenly breaks into quiet sobs. He comes back out, wearing a backpack, and notices Mom cr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying) Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the worst day of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew this day was coming. I just -- I didn't know you were gonna be so fuckin' happy to be leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, it's not that I'm that happy. What do you, what do you expect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I'm realizing? My life is just gonna go, like that! This series of milestones. Getting married, having kids, getting divorced, the time that we thought you were dyslexic, when I taught you how to ride a bike, getting divorced AGAIN, getting my masters degree, finally getting the job I wanted, sending Samantha off to college, sending YOU off the college... You know what's next? Huh? It's my fuckin' funeral! A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just go, and leave my picture! Stunned, Mason doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you jumping ahead by like, forty years or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just thought there would be more. Mom sits at the table crying.   Mason does not know how t comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason drives his pick-up truck through the open roads and mountains of West Texas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason stops at a gas station to fill up.   While he waits takes pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason pulls into the parking lot of his University and pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason walks through a hallway area and finds his dorm roo He enters to find it half decorated with music going. He throws his bag up on the available bed and starts to unpa and get situated. DALTON enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you must be Mason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Dalton, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, man, it's nice to finally meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Definitely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you cool with this side of the room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got in this morning, just moved my shit in, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Well, yeah. I don't- I don't care. No worries. He unzips his bag, but keeps the conversation going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool. Can I help with anything, man? Any bags? Any last stuff you need brought in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got like one... box left, I packed pretty light. But I appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure, man. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, are you goin' to the orientation mixer thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orientation mixer thing? Fuck no, man! I'm not goin' to that and neither are you, by the way. We got way better stuff to be doin', dude. BARB, Dalton's girlfriend, drifts into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hey, Barb, this' my roommate Mason. Mason, Barb. They shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.   You comin' with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where're you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, man, you should come. If we leave now we can catch the late afternoon at Big Bend. You ever been before, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But not since I was really little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well then all the more reason to come now, man. That's why we're here, dude. Barb's roommate, NICOLE, is now hanging out by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mason.   This is Nicole, Barb's roommate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Barb is reaching in her bag for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason, Nicole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mason) So, you game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. She has produced a chunk of brownie that she hands to Mas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Have the rest of this. Got it timed perfectly. It'll kick in when we get to the mountains. Mason takes it, a little amused, looks at the others (confirmation), then starts to consume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awesome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go. They roll out of there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason, Nicole, Dalton and Barb hike through a BIG canyon. Nicole talks to Mason about teaching dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do they let you major in that here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's not that serious here, so I kinda like train outside the university, but I'm taking all my basics like History of Dance and all that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you teach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, gosh. Ballet, tap, jazz, lyrical, hip-hop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.    Which one's your favorite?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. You can make up all your own sounds and there's no rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right...

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Just, like, creative freedom.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: That's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: ... So to be a part of bringing it back to the kids...

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Right, keep it going.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: ... Is really rewarding.   Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: How old are they?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Six to eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Wow.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Yeah. They have like no fear, and they're not self-conscious at all.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: They haven't reached the awkward years yet.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, not yet. It's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group continues walking over a ridge as the sun is setting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Barb and Dalton coyote call on the rocks, Mason joins Nicole sitting on a rock overlooking the river and sunset

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Dalton and Barb continue like coyotes, much to Nicole and Mason's amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dalton can be crazy sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems cool, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.     Yeah, they're both really cool.     How are you feeling? They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.    Really great, to be honest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. I'm really happy that you're hangin' out with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.     Me too. Meanwhile, over on a big rock, the coyotes are now yellin words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This moment's having a multiple orgasm! It's like as if all of time has unfolded before us so we can stand here and look out and scream - Fuck yea!! Wooo! Back with Nicole and Mason laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how everyone's always saying, "Seize the moment"? Mason nods yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I'm kinda thinkin' it's the other way around. You know, like, the moment seizes us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah, I know. It's constant, the moments, it's just... it's like always right now, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. They trade smiles.
